hints_html:
To determine the eigenvectors, we must solve the equation

\[\begin{aligned} (P - \lambda_{k} I)\mathbf{v}_{k} = 0\end{aligned}\]

where \(\lambda_{k}\) are the eigenvalues and vk are the eigenvectors.
hints_raw:
To determine the eigenvectors, we must solve the equation

:<math>
(P - \lambda_{k} I)\mathbf{v}_{k} = 0
</math>

where <math>\lambda_{k}</math> are the eigenvalues and '''v'''<sub>''k''</sub> are the eigenvectors.
question: B 03 (b)
sols_html:
To determine the eigenvectors, we must solve the equation

\[\begin{aligned} (P - \lambda_{k} I)\mathbf{v}_{k} = 0\end{aligned}\]

where \(\lambda_{k}\) are the eigenvalues and vk are the eigenvectors.

\(\lambda_{1} = 1\)

\[\begin{aligned} &(P - I)\mathbf{v}_{1} = \left[\begin{array}{cc} -2/3 & 1/4 \\ 2/3 & -1/4\end{array}\right]\mathbf{v}_{1} = 0 \\ & \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathbf{v}_{1} = \left[\begin{array}{c}1/4 \\ 2/3\end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

(Note that we are not normalizing the eigenvectors. It is not necessary to do so at this point.)

\(\lambda_{2} = 1/12\)

\[\begin{aligned} &(P - \frac{1}{12}I)\mathbf{v}_{2} = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/4 & 1/4 \\ 2/3 & 2/3\end{array}\right]\mathbf{v}_{2} = 0 \\ & \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathbf{v}_{2} = \left[\begin{array}{c}1 \\ -1\end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
To determine the eigenvectors, we must solve the equation

:<math>
(P - \lambda_{k} I)\mathbf{v}_{k} = 0
</math>

where <math>\lambda_{k}</math> are the eigenvalues and '''v'''<sub>''k''</sub> are the eigenvectors.

<b><math>\lambda_{1} = 1</math></b>

:<math>
\begin{align}
&(P - I)\mathbf{v}_{1} = \left[\begin{array}{cc} -2/3 & 1/4 \\ 2/3 & -1/4\end{array}\right]\mathbf{v}_{1} = 0 \\ & \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathbf{v}_{1} = \left[\begin{array}{c}1/4 \\ 2/3\end{array}\right]
\end{align}
</math>

(Note that we are not normalizing the eigenvectors. It is not necessary to do so at this point.)

<b><math>\lambda_{2} = 1/12</math></b>

:<math>
\begin{align}
&(P - \frac{1}{12}I)\mathbf{v}_{2} = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/4 & 1/4 \\ 2/3 & 2/3\end{array}\right]\mathbf{v}_{2} = 0 \\ & \quad \rightarrow \quad \mathbf{v}_{2} = \left[\begin{array}{c}1 \\ -1\end{array}\right]
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
A random walk problem with two states has a transition matrix

\[\begin{aligned} P = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/3 & 1/4 \\ 2/3 & 3/4\end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

b) The eigenvalues of \(P\) are 1 and 1/12. Find corresponding eigenvectors.
statement_raw:
A random walk problem with two states has a transition matrix

:<math>
P = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1/3 & 1/4 \\ 2/3 & 3/4\end{array}\right]
</math>

b) The eigenvalues of <math>P</math> are 1 and 1/12. Find corresponding eigenvectors.
